entries.text: Philippe Bruhat (BOOK) presents a problem with use of requires when working with roles, and also presents a solution.
entries.title: Of course you can `requires` attributes!
Using Roles as Partial Classes
entries.text: Curtis Poe (OVID) describes how roles can be treated as partial classes, a concept in some languages, where a class can be split into multiple files. A bit like roles, you might be thinking.

entries.title: Test-Simple release candidates
entries.text: Chad Granum (EXODIST) posted an update on changes to Test::Builder, Test::Simple, and Test::More. These changes will be part of Perl 5.22.

entries.title: Development release 001 of Catalyst 5.90080
entries.text: John Napiorkowski (JJNAPIORK) announces a developer release with a lot of fixes related to UTF-8 and encoding. "If you never bother to test development releases of Catalyst, this is the one time you really should".
Jeffrey Thalhammer (THALJEF) announced a developer release of a new version of Perl::Critic, which now uses MCE to run tests in parallel.
entries.title: Test::Perl::Critic Is Now Wicked Fast

chapters.text: The [Perl Maven Pro](http://perlmaven.com/pro) subscribers receive two new articles and screencasts every week. The last week these were the two screencasts:

entries.title: Add "404 Not Found" page
entries.text: Added a custom 404 error page to your project.
Something about protecting from a crash.
entries.title: Protecting from a crash

chapters.title: Perl Maven Pro

entries.text: Curtis Poe (OVID) posted a small programming challenge, and a bunch of people gave their solutions (in the comments, gists, etc).
entries.title: Pretty-printing multiple arrays
Adventures with XML
entries.text: Nestoria describe how they process a lot of data in XML using XML::Simple.
Gabor explains regular rexpression quantifiers, which specify how many of a given sub-pattern you want to match.
entries.title: Perl 5 Regex quantifiers
Time is a scarce resource
entries.text: Sinan Unur (NANIS) muses (more than once) on the right thing to do when you hit problems trying to install someone else's software. These resonated with me, since I spent way too long trying to get GD and GD::Graph working on a machine last week. Sometimes, when you've got the damn thing working, you're out of time and energy, and just need to move on. And sometimes not.

entries.title: NICEPERL's lists
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (VTI) interviewed Olaf Alders (OALDERS), the founder of MetaCPAN. Topics covered: how he got started in Perl, what led to MetaCPAN, and his current web framework of choice.
entries.title: Interview with Olaf Alders

entries.text: Each month Nestoria tip their hat, and wallet, to a favourite module. November's choice was Perl::Critic.
entries.title: Nestoria's module of the month: Perl::Critic

entries.text: Philippe Bruhat (BOOK) might count as a professional workshop organiser. He reports on a recent hackathon held in Lyon, without actually mentioning what they were hacking on.
entries.title: The patch -p2 hackathon in Lyon is over
First release of lib::projectroot
entries.text: Thomas Klausner (DOMM) has released lib::projectroot, which makes it easier to load all the project-specific, non-CPAN code ("DarkPAN") in your project's scripts

Robert Rothenberg (RRWO) has released a new version of Pod::Readme which has hooks for workin with Dist::Zilla. This means your pod can now include sections just for inclusion in the README, for example.
entries.title: Pod::Readme can now be used with Dist::Zilla

entries.text: Steve Cookson emailed the wxPerl mailing list, "After six years of graft and toil we have just launched our project  i-Mage at a medical conference in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil".
entries.title: i-Mage announced

entries.text: OTRS is an open-source ticketing system written in Perl (Wikipedia page). Version 4 was released recently; one of the changes was to move to the Template toolkit.
entries.title: What's new in OTRS 4?

entries.ts: Tony Cook (A<TONYC>) submitted his firstly monthly report for his fourth "Maintaining Perl 5" grant.
entries.title: Tony Cook's grant report
entries.text: This kind of work is critical to keeping Perl moving forward, and stopping the bit-rot.
Ingy and David describe their recent work to make "auto-stubbing" a reality. This lets you create lightweight modules in C using Inline, rather than going full-fat XS.
entries.title: Inline grant weekly report #7
The Perl 5 Advent Calendar
entries.text: Mark Fowler (MARKF) has been doing a sterling job on this advent calendar thus far, covering Test::TempDir::Tiny, Mac::Safari::JavaScript, HTTP::Tiny, Plack, Sub::Util, Test::DatabaseRow, and Time::Limit.

entries.title: The Perl 6 Advent Calendar
entries.text: A selection of authors have so far covered: The State of Perl 6 in 2014, Rakudobrew, Cap your junctions, Composers, Coercers, and the Case of a Camel’s Curious Corner, Act with great Responsibility, Running External Programs from Perl 6, and That’s how we .roll these days.

entries.title: PERLANCAR's Advent Calendar
entries.text: PERLANCAR is being greedy or impressive, or both, describing one of his 2014 modules each day. So far: App::jpath, App::nauniq, DBIx::Diff::Struct, App::datecalc, App::rmhere, File::umask, and App::SetScreensaverTimeout.
Matt Trout (MSTROUT) is giving his thoughts on themed modules each day. So far: web frameworks, web deployment, XML, HTML, Files,
entries.title: Matt Trout's Advent Posts
Dancer Advent Calendar
entries.text: The Dancer project have their own advent calendar too. Topics so far: Another year of Dancing, Starting anew, Migrating to Dancer 2, Your website in a Carton box, Packing the Fat, Static file serving in Dancer 2, and Doing an API mashup with Dancer.

header: Lots of Advent articles in the last week, and plenty more besides.
The articles are all written by volunteers — why not see if you can help out?
Developer releases of Catalyst and Perl::Critic need their tyres kicking, so get ya boots on!
subject: Advent ahoy!
